cards.flavor: The Summer Court remains above the conflicts of mortals and other fae alike, preferring to inspire from a distance.

cards.flavor: When Gwilym returned to his kingdom, he found that Aneirin, in his guise, had secured his borders, kept the peace, and repaired the roads.

cards.flavor:
“So, you would take my knight from me. Hold him close, then, and he just might bite your pretty little head off.”
—Queen Meif, to Sioned

cards.flavor: Bumedyn's youth are well-armed, bored, and disorganized; once Meiriona had proved her strength, they flocked to her promises of wealth and notoriety.

cards.flavor: Meiriona had hoped marrying Briallen would bring peace with Ilwyth at last—but Briallen had eyes only for Caerwyn.

cards.flavor:
“To Ilwyth, to take Gwilym's head for pillaging our land and killing our people—who's with me?”
—Meiriona

cards.flavor: “I am betrayed. What can I do but follow my heart?”

cards.flavor:
“The last thing we need now is for some hotheaded idiot to start a war trying to avenge me. And of course Caersedd has no shortage of idiots.”
—Meredith

cards.flavor:
“We are beset! Could my apprentice borrow a blade?”
—Emrys, the magician

cards.flavor: As Caersedd's knights crashed into the Winter Court raiders' flank, Sioned tried to focus on the battle, but Tomos' plea wouldn't leave her mind.

cards.flavor: Xenocrata's decades of fighting all-out wars on grand battlefields proved of little use dueling warriors who'd spent their life defending their honor in single combat.

cards.flavor: Aneirin hoped his enemies would tip their hands by moving against Gwilym. He was pleasantly surprised when Gwilym simply destroyed them instead.

cards.flavor: They cannot stop for faerie raiders nor winter's chill; they carry news that must get through to the king in Caersedd.

cards.flavor: “Sure, the claws and teeth of Winter's wolves are sharp—but so's Glyndrol iron, and I'm the one who walked away after.”

cards.flavor: Meredith knew that King Aneirin would never jeopardize his alliance with Ilwyth; someone else had to be behind the assassinations. Caersedd had no such trust in the fae.

“I'm afraid you can't turn it down—not if you want to keep your army, that is.”
—Traherne, to Xenocrata

cards.flavor:
“I can no longer trust my eyes. I'll turn myself in for what I've done, but not yet. Not until I find the source of the nightmares.”
—Heddwyn

cards.flavor: Gwaredd was far stronger than Meiriona and a head taller; even once she started killing other knights, he felt he had nothing to fear. By the time he saw her ambush, he was already dead.
cards.name: Ilwyth Cunning
cards.originalText: Untap target attacking creature and put two +1/+1 counters on it. It gains trample until end of turn.
cards.text: Untap target attacking creature and put two +1/+1 counters on it. It gains trample until end of turn.

cards.name: Into the Fire
cards.originalText: Exile the top two cards of your library. You may play those cards this turn. Invoke. (Look at the top five cards of your library. You may reveal a sorcery card from among them and put it on top of your library. Put the rest on the bottom in a random order.)

cards.flavor:
“For the favor you owe, do this for me: You'll take my face and I yours, and we'll rule each other's courts for a year and a day.”
—Aneirin, to Gwilym
cards.name: Journey into Autumn
cards.originalText: Search your library for a card, put it into your graveyard, then shuffle your library. You may return a land card from your graveyard to the battlefield tapped.
cards.text: Search your library for a card, put it into your graveyard, then shuffle your library. You may return a land card from your graveyard to the battlefield tapped.

cards.flavor: For years, Tshosiech worked slowly and subtly, twisting minds and corrupting dreams. Only then did the nightmares slip from thought into reality.
cards.name: Living Dreams
cards.originalText: Create two 3/2 black Nightmare creature tokens.
cards.text: Create two 3/2 black Nightmare creature tokens.

cards.flavor: Tshosiech's defeat left it with time enough to bury most of the evidence of its schemes.
cards.name: Loose Ends
cards.originalText: Destroy target creature. Sacrifice a permanent unless you cast another sorcery spell this turn.
cards.text: Destroy target creature. Sacrifice a permanent unless you cast another sorcery spell this turn.

cards.flavor: Young knights of Glyndrol are warned not to wander into Coebryn Glen; a cursed knight haunts it, and none who go there leave unchanged.
cards.name: Lost Squire
cards.originalText: Lost Squire has vigilance as long as you control another Knight.
cards.text: Lost Squire has vigilance as long as you control another Knight.

cards.name: Mask of the Wicked
cards.originalText:
When Mask of the Wicked enters the battlefield, plot. (Choose a card name, then reveal the top card of your library. Put that card into your hand if it has the chosen name. Otherwise, put it back or mill it.)
Whenever you plot, if you revealed a permanent card, you may have Mask of the Wicked become a copy of it. If you do, it gains this ability.

cards.name: Mask of the Wolf Pack

cards.flavor:
“I'm afraid I lied; they were mere illusions. But you've armed my nephew and broken the curse you set him, so we'll be on our way.”
—Emrys, the magician
cards.name: Meif's Gift
cards.originalText:

cards.flavor: Mortal borders are no barrier to the Winter Queen's knights. Mortal heroes blocking the only ford across the Aberffin, however...
cards.name: Meif's Raider
cards.originalText: Whenever Meif's Raider deals combat damage to an opponent, return target creature that player controls to its owner's hand.
cards.text: Whenever Meif's Raider deals combat damage to an opponent, return target creature that player controls to its owner's hand.

cards.flavor: “The arrogant princess repeats her father's mistakes. Remind her that she is only mortal, and that nothing she holds can last.”
cards.name: Meif, Queen of Winter
cards.originalText:
Flash
Whenever Meif, Queen of Winter deals combat damage to an opponent, that player can't untap more than one land during their next untap step.
cards.text:
Flash
Whenever Meif, Queen of Winter deals combat damage to an opponent, that player can't untap more than one land during their next untap step.

cards.flavor: Meiriona knew she couldn't get her vengeance alone, but she'd need to prove herself before anyone would follow her.

cards.flavor: Twelve fathers slain, twelve deaths avenged.

cards.name: Meredith, Hidden Survivor
cards.originalText:
[+1]: Until end of turn, Meredith becomes a 3/3 Human Druid creature with trample that's still a planeswalker. Prevent all damage that would be dealt to them this turn. Whenever they deal damage to an opponent this turn, draw a card.
[-1]: Until your next turn, if a source would deal 3 or less damage, prevent that damage.
[-7]: Return each card from your graveyard to your hand. You get an emblem with “You have no maximum hand size.”

cards.flavor: “Test my skill against the Winter Queen's? Not for all the gold in Ilwyth and all the secrets in Eigion.”

cards.flavor:
“I'll ride with a company of fae knights, but you'll find me easily enough; only my horse will be of flesh and blood, not lies and mist.”
—Tomos, to Sioned
cards.name: Phantom Escort

cards.flavor: “You're quite a charming one, apprentice. What's your name?” The prince grinned, understanding his uncle's scheme at last. “Apprentice,” he replied.
cards.name: Princely Ploy

When Princely Ploy enters the battlefield, draw a card, then choose a nonland card name.
Whenever you cast a spell with the chosen name, untap up to two target permanents.

cards.flavor: Whether across the sea to slay a king or in pursuit of one of their own, Meiriona's warriors would follow her anywhere.

cards.flavor: Meredith knew that whatever tried to kill them, it wouldn't expect them to be back. With their contacts among the witches hiding them, they might have a chance to find it and catch it by surprise.
cards.name: Roseblossom Witch

cards.text: {W}, {T}: Target creature gains flying until end of turn.

cards.flavor: As her rhyfelwyr looted and burned Ilwyth, Meiriona pushed ahead, revenge in sight.

cards.flavor:
“Then Sioned rode out bold as all / To Aberffin's waters wide / To face the raiders one by one / No two could go beside.”
—“The Raiding of Glyndrol”
cards.name: Seize the Ford

cards.text: Destroy each creature blocking target attacking creature. That creature becomes unblocked.

cards.flavor: With each city blasted into ruin, new warriors joined Xenocrata's forces—some intimidated, some impressed, and some just lacking a home to return to.

cards.flavor: Queen Meif's curse left the prince unfit to rule, so King Gwilym sent his son to Eigion, where he could study with his uncle Emrys's finest sages.

cards.flavor: “The faeries think they're the only ones who can sneak across borders? They'll think again when they wake to empty pastures and mocking laughs.”

cards.flavor: “This is my land as it was my father's; there's not an acre of it I'd fear to ride through or fight for. If Meif wants to take it, she can die trying.”

cards.flavor:
“Beautifully done, Caerwyn! Truly you're the greatest hero in Bumedyn.”
—Briallen

cards.flavor: The Spring and Autumn Courts each love transformation, but see the process differently. To the fae of Spring, it's an act of rebirth; to those of Autumn, a symbolic death.

cards.flavor:
“Just having more fire than the enemy doesn't win wars. Fire in the right place at the right time wins wars.”
—Xenocrata

cards.flavor:
“You're very beautiful, but I will not betray my friend's trust—and if I was the kind of man who would, I wouldn't deserve you or her.”
—Caerwyn

“Tactics is the art of other people making mistakes.”

“I need a trinket to ward my dreams, and I'll pay triple if you tell nobody I'm still alive.”
